conclusion: To find the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the current-carrying wire, we need to calculate the magnetic flux and use it to determine the force.
The magnetic flux through a rectangular loop is given by the formula Φ = B ⋅ A, where A is the area of the loop and B is the magnetic induction intensity.
The wire is folded into a right-angle shape with side lengths ac = L and cd = 2L.
The area of the rectangular loop can be calculated as A = ac × cd = L × 2L = 2L².
The magnetic induction intensity B is given by B = (μ₀ I) / (2L), where μ₀ is the permeability of free space and I is the current.
Substituting the values, the magnetic flux Φ is calculated as Φ = B ⋅ A = (μ₀ I / 2L) ⋅ 2L² = μ₀ I L².
The Ampere force F on a current-carrying wire is given by F = μ₀ I L² × (B / 2L).
Simplifying the expression for the Ampere force, F = μ₀ I L² × (B / 2L) = (μ₀ I B) / 2.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the current-carrying wire is (μ₀ I B) / 2.
